entry.title: Codeforces 1605C. Dominant Character
entry.content:
Ashish has a string ss of length nn containing only characters â€˜aâ€˜, â€˜bâ€˜ and â€˜câ€˜.

He wants to find the length of the smallest substring, which satisfies the following conditions:

  • Length of the substring is at least 22
  • â€˜aâ€˜ occurs strictly more times in this substring than â€˜bâ€˜
  • â€˜aâ€˜ occurs strictly more times in this substring than â€˜câ€˜

Ashish is busy planning his next Codeforces round. Help him solve the problem.

A string aa is a substring of a string bb if aa can be obtained from bb by deletion of several (possibly, zero or all) characters from the beginning and several (possibly, zero or all) characters from the end.

InputThe first line contains a single integer tt (1 \le t \le 10^{5})(1â‰¤tâ‰¤105**)** â€” the number of test cases. The description of test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (2 \le n \le 10^{6})(2â‰¤nâ‰¤106**)** â€” the length of the string ss.

The second line of each test case contains a string ss consisting only of characters â€˜aâ€˜, â€˜bâ€˜ and â€˜câ€˜.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 10^{6}106.

OutputFor each test case, output the length of the smallest substring which satisfies the given conditions or print -1âˆ’1 if there is no such substring.

Sample 1

Input

output

note

NoteConsider the first test case. In the substring â€œaaâ€œ, â€˜aâ€˜ occurs twice, while â€˜bâ€˜ and â€˜câ€˜ occur zero times. Since â€˜aâ€˜ occurs strictly more times than â€˜bâ€˜ and â€˜câ€˜, the substring â€œaaâ€œ satisfies the condition and the answer is 22. The substring â€œaâ€œ also satisfies this condition, however its length is not at least 22.

In the second test case, it can be shown that in none of the substrings of â€œcbabbâ€œ does â€˜aâ€˜ occur strictly more times than â€˜bâ€˜ and â€˜câ€˜ each.

In the third test case, â€œcacabcccâ€œ, the length of the smallest substring that satisfies the conditions is 33.

code

entry.title: Codeforces 39D. Cubical Planet
entry.content:
You can find anything whatsoever in our Galaxy! A cubical planet goes round an icosahedral star. Let us introduce a system of axes so that the edges of the cubical planet are parallel to the coordinate axes and two opposite vertices lay in the points (0,â€‰0,â€‰0) and (1,â€‰1,â€‰1). Two flies live on the planet. At the moment they are sitting on two different vertices of the cubical planet. Your task is to determine whether they see each other or not. The flies see each other when the vertices they occupy lie on the same face of the cube.

InputThe first line contains three space-separated integers (0 or 1) â€” the coordinates of the first fly, the second line analogously contains the coordinates of the second fly.

OutputOutput â€œYESâ€ (without quotes) if the flies see each other. Otherwise, output â€œNOâ€.

Sample 1

Input

output

Sample 2

Input

output

Sample 3

Input

output

code

entry.title: Codeforces 1255B. Fridge Lockers
entry.content:
Hanh lives in a shared apartment. There are nn people (including Hanh) living there, each has a private fridge.

nn fridges are secured by several steel chains. Each steel chain connects two different fridges and is protected by a digital lock. The owner of a fridge knows passcodes of all chains connected to it. A fridge can be open only if all chains connected to it are unlocked. For example, if a fridge has no chains connected to it at all, then any of nn people can open it.

For exampe, in the picture there are n=4n=4 people and 55 chains. The first person knows passcodes of two chains: 1âˆ’41âˆ’4 and 1âˆ’21âˆ’2**. The fridge** 11 can be open by its owner (the person 11**), also two people** 22 and 44 (acting together) can open it.The weights of these fridges are a1,a2,â€¦,ana1,a2,â€¦,an. To make a steel chain connecting fridges uu and vv, you have to pay au**+av**au+av dollars. Note that the landlord allows you to create multiple chains connecting the same pair of fridges.

Hanhâ€™s apartment landlord asks you to create exactly mm steel chains so that all fridges are private. A fridge is private if and only if, among nn people living in the apartment, only the owner can open it (i.e. no other person acting alone can do it). In other words, the fridge ii is not private if there exists the person jj (iâ‰ jiâ‰ j) that the person jj can open the fridge ii.

For example, in the picture all the fridges are private. On the other hand, if there are n=2n=2 fridges and only one chain (which connects them) then both fridges are not private (both fridges can be open not only by its owner but also by another person).

Of course, the landlord wants to minimize the total cost of all steel chains to fulfill his request. Determine whether there exists any way to make exactly mm chains, and if yes, output any solution that minimizes the total cost.

Input

Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases TT (1â‰¤Tâ‰¤101â‰¤Tâ‰¤10). Then the descriptions of the test cases follow.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn, mm (2â‰¤nâ‰¤10002â‰¤nâ‰¤1000, 1â‰¤mâ‰¤n1â‰¤mâ‰¤n) â€” the number of people living in Hanhâ€™s apartment and the number of steel chains that the landlord requires, respectively.

The second line of each test case contains nn integers a1**,a2**,â€¦,ana1,a2,â€¦,an (0â‰¤aiâ‰¤1040â‰¤aiâ‰¤104) â€” weights of all fridges.

Output

For each test case:

  • If there is no solution, print a single integer âˆ’1âˆ’1.
  • Otherwise, print a single integer cc â€” the minimum total cost. The ii-th of the next mm lines contains two integers uiui and vivi (1â‰¤ui**,viâ‰¤n1â‰¤ui,viâ‰¤n, uiâ‰ vi**uiâ‰ vi), meaning that the ii-th steel chain connects fridges uiui and vivi. An arbitrary number of chains can be between a pair of fridges.

If there are multiple answers, print any.

Example

input

output

code

entry.title: Codeforces 1744C. Traffic Light
entry.content:
C. Traffic Light
time limit per test1 second
memory limit per test256 megabytes
inputstandard input
outputstandard output
You find yourself on an unusual crossroad with a weird traffic light. That traffic light has three possible colors: red (r), yellow (y), green (g). It is known that the traffic light repeats its colors every n seconds and at the i-th second the color si is on.

That way, the order of the colors is described by a string. For example, if s=â€rggryâ€, then the traffic light works as the following: red-green-green-red-yellow-red-green-green-red-yellow- â€¦ and so on.

More formally, you are given a string s1,s2,â€¦,sn of length n. At the first second the color s1 is on, at the second â€” s2, â€¦, at the n-th second the color sn is on, at the n+1-st second the color s1 is on and so on.

You need to cross the road and that can only be done when the green color is on.

You know which color is on the traffic light at the moment, but you donâ€™t know the current moment of time. You need to find the minimum amount of time in which you are guaranteed to cross the road.

You can assume that you cross the road immediately.

For example, with s=â€rggryâ€ and the current color r there are two options: either the green color will be on after 1 second, or after 3. That way, the answer is equal to 3 â€” that is the number of seconds that we are guaranteed to cross the road, if the current color is r.

Input
The first line contains a single integer t (1â‰¤tâ‰¤104) â€” the number of test cases.

Then the description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains an integer n and a symbol c (1â‰¤nâ‰¤2â‹…105, c is one of allowed traffic light colors r, y or g)â€” the length of the string s and the current color of the traffic light.

The second line of each test case contains a string s of the length n, consisting of the letters r, y and g.

It is guaranteed that the symbol g is in the string s and the symbol c is in the string s.

It is guaranteed, that the sum of n over all test cases does not exceed 2â‹…105.

Output
For each test case output the minimal number of second in which you are guaranteed to cross the road.

Example
inputCopy
6
5 r
rggry
1 g
g
3 r
rrg
5 y
yrrgy
7 r
rgrgyrg
9 y
rrrgyyygy
outputCopy
3
0
2
4
1
4
Note
The first test case is explained in the statement.

In the second test case the green color is on so you can cross the road immediately.

In the third test case, if the red color was on at the second second, then we would wait for the green color for one second, and if the red light was on at the first second, then we would wait for the green light for two seconds.

In the fourth test case the longest we would wait for the green color is if we wait for it starting from the fifth second.

entry.title: Codeforces 1744D. Divisibility by 2^n
entry.content:
D. Divisibility by 2^n
time limit per test2 seconds
memory limit per test256 megabytes
inputstandard input
outputstandard output
You are given an array of positive integers a1,a2,â€¦,an.

Make the product of all the numbers in the array (that is, a1â‹…a2â‹…â€¦â‹…an) divisible by 2n.

You can perform the following operation as many times as you like:

select an arbitrary index i (1â‰¤iâ‰¤n) and replace the value ai with ai=aiâ‹…i.
You cannot apply the operation repeatedly to a single index. In other words, all selected values of i must be different.

Find the smallest number of operations you need to perform to make the product of all the elements in the array divisible by 2n. Note that such a set of operations does not always exist.

Input
The first line of the input contains a single integer t (1â‰¤tâ‰¤104) â€” the number test cases.

Then the descriptions of the input data sets follow.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer n (1â‰¤nâ‰¤2â‹…105) â€” the length of array a.

The second line of each test case contains exactly n integers: a1,a2,â€¦,an (1â‰¤aiâ‰¤109).

It is guaranteed that the sum of n values over all test cases in a test does not exceed 2â‹…105.

Output
For each test case, print the least number of operations to make the product of all numbers in the array divisible by 2n. If the answer does not exist, print -1.

Example
inputCopy
6
1
2
2
3 2
3
10 6 11
4
13 17 1 1
5
1 1 12 1 1
6
20 7 14 18 3 5
outputCopy
0
1
1
-1
2
1
Note
In the first test case, the product of all elements is initially 2, so no operations needed.

In the second test case, the product of elements initially equals 6. We can apply the operation for i=2, and then a2 becomes 2â‹…2=4, and the product of numbers becomes 3â‹…4=12, and this product of numbers is divided by 2n=22=4.

In the fourth test case, even if we apply all possible operations, we still cannot make the product of numbers divisible by 2n â€” it will be (13â‹…1)â‹…(17â‹…2)â‹…(1â‹…3)â‹…(1â‹…4)=5304, which does not divide by 2n=24=16.

In the fifth test case, we can apply operations for i=2 and i=4.

entry.title: Codeforces 1744B. Even-Odd Increments
entry.content:
time limit per test2 seconds
memory limit per test256 megabytes
inputstandard input
outputstandard output
You are given n of integers a1,a2,â€¦,an. Process q queries of two types:

query of the form â€œ0 xjâ€: add the value xj to all even elements of the array a,
query of the form â€œ1 xjâ€: add the value xj to all odd elements of the array a.
Note that when processing the query, we look specifically at the odd/even value of ai, not its index.

After processing each query, print the sum of the elements of the array a.

Please note that the answer for some test cases wonâ€™t fit into 32-bit integer type, so you should use at least 64-bit integer type in your programming language (like long long for C++).

Input
The first line of the input contains an integer t (1â‰¤tâ‰¤104) â€” the number of test cases.

The descriptions of the test cases follow.

The first line of each test case contains two integers n and q (1â‰¤n, qâ‰¤105) â€” the length of array a and the number of queries.

The second line of each test case contains exactly n integers: a1,a2,â€¦,an (1â‰¤aiâ‰¤109) â€” elements of the array a.

The following q lines contain queries as two integers typej and xj (0â‰¤typejâ‰¤1, 1â‰¤xjâ‰¤104).

It is guaranteed that the sum of values n over all test cases in a test does not exceed 105. Similarly, the sum of values q over all test cases does not exceed 105.

Output
For each test case, print q numbers: the sum of the elements of the array a after processing a query.

Example
inputCopy
4
1 1
1
1 1
3 3
1 2 4
0 2
1 3
0 5
6 7
1 3 2 4 10 48
1 6
0 5
0 4
0 5
1 3
0 12
0 1
6 7
1000000000 1000000000 1000000000 11 15 17
0 17
1 10000
1 51
0 92
0 53
1 16
0 1
outputCopy
2
11
14
29
80
100
100
100
118
190
196
3000000094
3000060094
3000060400
3000060952
3000061270
3000061366
3000061366
Note
In the first test case, the array a=[2] after the first query.

In the third test case, the array a is modified as follows: [1,3,2,4,10,48] â†’ [7,9,2,4,10,48] â†’ [7,9,7,9,15,53] â†’ [7,9,7,9,15,53] â†’ [10,12,10,12,18,56] â†’ [22,24,22,24,30,68] â†’ [23,25,23,25,31,69].

entry.title: Codeforces 1744A. Number Replacement
entry.content:
A. Number Replacement
time limit per test2 seconds
memory limit per test256 megabytes
inputstandard input
outputstandard output
An integer array a1,a2,â€¦,an is being transformed into an array of lowercase English letters using the following prodecure:

While there is at least one number in the array:

Choose any number x from the array a, and any letter of the English alphabet y.
Replace all occurrences of number x with the letter y.
For example, if we initially had an array a=[2,3,2,4,1], then we could transform it the following way:

Choose the number 2 and the letter c. After that a=[c,3,c,4,1].
Choose the number 3 and the letter a. After that a=[c,a,c,4,1].
Choose the number 4 and the letter t. After that a=[c,a,c,t,1].
Choose the number 1 and the letter a. After that a=[c,a,c,t,a].
After the transformation all letters are united into a string, in our example we get the string â€œcactaâ€.

Having the array a and the string s determine if the string s could be got from the array a after the described transformation?

Input
The first line contains a single integer t (1â‰¤tâ‰¤103) â€” the number of test cases.

Then the description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer n (1â‰¤nâ‰¤50) â€” the length of the array a and the string s.

The second line of each test case contains exactly n integers: a1,a2,â€¦,an (1â‰¤aiâ‰¤50) â€” the elements of the array a.

The third line of each test case contains a string s of length n, consisting of lowercase English letters.

Output
For each test case, output â€œYESâ€, if we can get the string s from the array a, and â€œNOâ€ otherwise. You can output each letter in any case.

Example
inputCopy
7
5
2 3 2 4 1
cacta
1
50
a
2
11 22
ab
4
1 2 2 1
aaab
5
1 2 3 2 1
aaaaa
6
1 10 2 9 3 8
azzfdb
7
1 2 3 4 1 1 2
abababb
outputCopy
YES
YES
YES
NO
YES
YES
NO
Note
The first test case corresponds to the sample described in the statement.

In the second test case we can choose the number 50 and the letter a.

In the third test case we can choose the number 11 and the letter a, after that a=[a,22]. Then we choose the number 22 and the letter b and get a=[a,b].

In the fifth test case we can change all numbers one by one to the letter a.

entry.title: Codeforces 1750B. Maximum Substring
entry.content:
B. Maximum Substring

A binary string is a string consisting only of the characters 0 and 1. You are given a binary string s.

For some non-empty substringâ€  t of string s containing x characters 0 and y characters 1, define its cost as:

xâ‹…y, if x>0 and y>0;
x2, if x>0 and y=0;
y2, if x=0 and y>0.
Given a binary string s of length n, find the maximum cost across all its non-empty substrings.

â€  A string a is a substring of a string b if a can be obtained from b by deletion of several (possibly, zero or all) characters from the beginning and several (possibly, zero or all) characters from the end.

Input
Each test consists of multiple test cases. The first line contains a single integer t (1â‰¤tâ‰¤105) â€” the number of test cases. The description of test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer n (1â‰¤nâ‰¤2â‹…105) â€” the length of the string s.

The second line of each test case contains a binary string s of length n.

It is guaranteed that the sum of n over all test cases does not exceed 2â‹…105.

Output
For each test case, print a single integer â€” the maximum cost across all substrings.

Example
inputCopy
6
5
11100
7
1100110
6
011110
7
1001010
4
1000
1
0
outputCopy
9
12
16
12
9
1
Note
In the first test case, we can take a substring 111. It contains 3 characters 1 and 0 characters 0. So a=3, b=0 and its cost is 32=9.

In the second test case, we can take the whole string. It contains 4 characters 1 and 3 characters 0. So a=4, b=3 and its cost is 4â‹…3=12.

In the third test case, we can can take a substring 1111 and its cost is 42=16.

In the fourth test case, we can take the whole string and cost is 4â‹…3=12.

In the fifth test case, we can take a substring 000 and its cost is 3â‹…3=9.

In the sixth test case, we can only take the substring 0 and its cost is 1â‹…1=1.

æ°´

entry.title: Codeforces 1750A. Indirect Sort
entry.content:
A. Indirect Sort

You are given a permutation a1,a2,â€¦,an of size n, where each integer from 1 to n appears exactly once.

You can do the following operation any number of times (possibly, zero):

Choose any three indices i,j,k (1â‰¤i<j<kâ‰¤n).
If ai>ak, replace ai with ai+aj. Otherwise, swap aj and ak.
Determine whether you can make the array a sorted in non-descending order.

Input
Each test consists of multiple test cases. The first line contains a single integer t (1â‰¤tâ‰¤5000) â€” the number of test cases. The description of test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer n (3â‰¤nâ‰¤10) â€” the length of the array a.

The second line contains n integers a1,a2,â€¦,an (1â‰¤aiâ‰¤n, aiâ‰ aj if iâ‰ j) â€” the elements of the array a.

Output
For each test case, output â€œYesâ€ (without quotes) if the array can be sorted in non-descending order, and â€œNoâ€ (without quotes) otherwise.

You can output â€œYesâ€ and â€œNoâ€ in any case (for example, strings â€œYESâ€, â€œyEsâ€ and â€œyesâ€ will be recognized as a positive response).

Example
inputCopy
7
3
1 2 3
3
1 3 2
7
5 3 4 7 6 2 1
7
7 6 5 4 3 2 1
5
2 1 4 5 3
5
2 1 3 4 5
7
1 2 6 7 4 3 5
outputCopy
Yes
Yes
No
No
No
No
Yes
Note
In the first test case, [1,2,3] is already sorted in non-descending order.

In the second test case, we can choose i=1,j=2,k=3. Since a1â‰¤a3, swap a2 and a3, the array then becomes [1,2,3], which is sorted in non-descending order.

In the seventh test case, we can do the following operations successively:

Choose i=5,j=6,k=7. Since a5â‰¤a7, swap a6 and a7, the array then becomes [1,2,6,7,4,5,3].
Choose i=5,j=6,k=7. Since a5>a7, replace a5 with a5+a6=9, the array then becomes [1,2,6,7,9,5,3].
Choose i=2,j=5,k=7. Since a2â‰¤a7, swap a5 and a7, the array then becomes [1,2,6,7,3,5,9].
Choose i=2,j=4,k=6. Since a2â‰¤a6, swap a4 and a6, the array then becomes [1,2,6,5,3,7,9].
Choose i=1,j=3,k=5. Since a1â‰¤a5, swap a3 and a5, the array then becomes [1,2,3,5,6,7,9], which is sorted in non-descending order.
In the third, the fourth, the fifth and the sixth test cases, it can be shown that the array cannot be sorted in non-descending order.

entry.title: å®éªŒå®¤ç¬¬äºŒæ¬¡è®²è¯¾
entry.content:
å®éªŒå®¤ç¬¬äºŒæ¬¡è®²è¯¾

#47. æ—¶é—´è½¬æ¢

è¯´æ˜

ç»™å®šä¸€ä¸ªä»¥ç§’ä¸ºå•ä½çš„æ—¶é—´tï¼Œè¦æ±‚ç”¨çš„æ ¼å¼æ¥è¡¨ç¤ºè¿™ä¸ªæ—¶é—´ã€‚<H>è¡¨ç¤ºæ—¶é—´ï¼Œ<M>è¡¨ç¤ºåˆ†é’Ÿï¼Œè€Œè¡¨ç¤ºç§’ï¼Œå®ƒä»¬éƒ½æ˜¯æ•´æ•°ä¸”æ²¡æœ‰å‰å¯¼çš„â€œ0â€ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œè‹¥t=0ï¼Œåˆ™åº”è¾“å‡ºæ˜¯â€œâ€ï¼›è‹¥t=3661ï¼Œåˆ™è¾“å‡ºâ€œâ€ã€‚

è¾“å…¥æ ¼å¼

è¾“å…¥åªæœ‰ä¸€è¡Œï¼Œæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ•´æ•°tï¼ˆ0<=t<=86399ï¼‰ã€‚

è¾“å‡ºæ ¼å¼

è¾“å‡ºåªæœ‰ä¸€è¡Œï¼Œæ˜¯ä»¥â€œâ€çš„æ ¼å¼æ‰€è¡¨ç¤ºçš„æ—¶é—´ï¼Œä¸åŒ…æ‹¬å¼•å·ã€‚

æ ·ä¾‹

è¾“å…¥æ•°æ® 1

è¾“å‡ºæ•°æ® 1

#18. ABCæ¯”å¤§å°

è¯´æ˜

è¿™é“é¢˜å¾ˆç®€å•ï¼Œè¾“å…¥ä¸‰ä¸ªæ•°å­—ï¼Œåªéœ€æŒ‰ç…§ä»–ä»¬çš„å¤§å°æ’å¥½åºå°±è¡Œã€‚

è¾“å…¥æ ¼å¼
